pros: CMU should be commended for its focus on creating a diverse community. It is a well know and respectable institution to work for with good people and a well oiled hybrid work model that benefits everyone. The employee benefits and 403B plan are really good as well as their PTO accrual. A truly amazing work/life balance
cons: Like every other billion dollar business, the money brought by in by donors, grants and exorbitant tuition doesn't make its way to the staff who keep the university running. They instead are reliant upon the individual colleges approved grant amounts which are often times so low that 1 staff members salary has to be split between 2 different departments, while the big money goes to executives, tenured faculty and new buildings around campus that aren't necessary. Every year, staff members are lucky to see a 2% salary increase while the amount of work they have doubles. And being that is a college, they also tend to require at least a Bachelors for the smallest of administrative positions who offer less than $25 hour. And to make things worse, the do not pay you for 40 hours a week. They instead opt of the 37.5 model which means even if you do manage to find a position within the university that pays $25/hr, you still will be under $50K a year.

pros: CMU has a remarkable culture and treats employees very well.
cons: Nothing bad to say - truly a great place to work

pros: In Pittsburgh, CMU brings together some of the most intelligent, forward thinking, and diverse undergraduate, graduate and PhD students from all over the world. As an internationally renowned establishment, it's quite difficult to land a full-time staff position without having a direct departmental network or contact. TES enables project based support to different departments across the university. The vast array of assignments provide an external candidate with the ability to gain daily insight into the university's work environment while also providing the flexibility to gain access to a wide array of positions that are typically short term assignments.
cons: It takes a special person to be able to be an outsider and acquire approval from the people you work with. Be prepared to be treated as someone that is not a full-time fixture or staff member. It's a hard gig to make worth while, however, if I could manage it then anyone could. The pay is very low, the benefits aren't great until you are in fact a full-time employee. Also, be prepared to pay or arrange for parking each day which can be hard to acquire if the lot is full or if it's a busy day on campus with street/hourly parking.

pros: As a graduate student at CMU, I have had an overall positive experience. The faculty members in my department are knowledgeable and approachable, and have provided valuable guidance and support throughout my studies. The coursework has been challenging but rewarding, and I feel that I have gained a strong foundation in my field. One of the standout features of CMU is the access to resources and facilities. The library has an extensive collection of books, journals, and online resources, and there are plenty of study spaces available. The campus also has a number of modern research labs and equipment that have allowed me to conduct my own experiments and projects. In terms of student life, there are a variety of clubs and organizations to get involved in, as well as a number of recreational and fitness facilities. The campus is located in a safe and convenient area, with easy access to local amenities and transportation. Overall, I am pleased with my decision to attend CMU for my graduate studies and would recommend it to others.
cons: The chemistry building (Mellon Institute) is not pleasant to work in. The building is outdated and uncomfortable especially during the winter time due to poor temperature control.

pros: There's nothing quite like a school environment to facilitate networking opportunities. You'll learn a lot from your peers, classes, and research while being able to take advantage of campus amenities.

pros: I really enjoyed my time working at CMU. Friendly and mostly down to earth people, though everyone has good and bad days. Working in an academic department is a mini-education in itself; you can learn a lot about the academic subject and research field if you’re curious and want to gain an extra benefit. Good selection of benefits (including education) and helpful/available HR staff.
cons: I worked in a few departments during my time as a temporary employee and while my overall perspective of my time here is positive, some departments that I worked in had low morale. In one office I worked in (non-academic), people would barely say hello to me as a temp. Other departments made me feel more welcome and as though my work really mattered. Not that one! Some people on the higher rungs of the ladder are hard to work with. It is hard to advance here since jobs are so competitive. The university is also very siloed; collaboration across campus must be deliberate.

review_title: Part-time Federal Work Study in the CMU Bookstore (Lower Level)
job_title: Federal Work Study in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
I was trained to be a cashier and quickly ready to assist customers. If I needed help with any transactions, a veteran employee or manager was always happy to aid me. This was my first job as a cashier, and I now have those skills should I ever need them again.
There were opportunities to get a little creative with the display of novelty items and  books. During the time I was there, I was also able to choose what music to play in the store.
During slow times, I had time to work on my homework. This was really important because I could not have kept up with homework otherwise, and I would have had to leave the job. 
After a year, I was given a pay raise.
Other employees and managers are very helpful and friendly, both as professionals and as people. I can depend on my former manager for future job recommendations.
cons:
I think this job is pretty straightforward, and it never gave me anything to complain about. 
The job didn't entail much stress. I was a federal workstudy employee. At the level I was employed at, I was not responsible for resolving major issues in the store. Whenever I had a problem (i.e., with a payment method, a return, a customer, damaged or lost stock), all I had to do was ask my manager.
During the time I was there, major construction on the CUC building sometimes affected the air quality in the store. This is no longer an issue since construction has been completed.

pros: The benefits package was great with many choices for healthcare for full time employees. Most of the coworkers that I knew there were great people as well.
cons:
If you are a faculty member or researcher then you will love this place. However, if you are in the support fields such as administrative support, computer network/systems support, lab or technical support you will dread waking up every day to go to work. Faculty, departmental and higher level management treat these support professional as if they were less than human. You will be forced to work long hours to complete tasks that should have multiple team members assigned. You will be denied assistance for these projects. 

HR will report your complaints to your department managers almost immediately, completely ignoring confidentiality. This will cause your departmental management to treat you even worse because you complained about them. 

You will receive very low pay for the position that you have. You will be asked to work extended hours to complete your projects but will be told not to report your overtime. When you go to HR about this you will be told by them to work smarter.

Luckily I was able to escape from there to a much better position outside of the education spectrum. I'm now considered one of the most valuable employees in my department. 

Within 6 months after I left there was a purge of many long-time employees across many departments. I spoke with many people that this happened to and the story was the same. Management came to each of the employees that I spoke with and asked them to gather their personal items and leave because they were no longer needed. Some of these people gave the university 5-10 even up to 30 years of service.

review_title: Experience is part of your compensation.
pros: Work with brilliant people developing cutting edge technologies, often 10+ years on the horizon. It's easy to advance within the university. Excellent benefits, tremendous access to education, resources and brilliant advice. Employees can take classes! It's easy to inspire incredibly capable students to work on projects with you. A great place to learn about the state of the art before founding a startup (and for meeting co-founders)! Staff members are able to license tech IP they develop from the university and create spin-off companies for commercialization.
cons: Academia is bureaucratic. Consider than 50% of your compensation is the experience and adjust your finances accordingly (this does not hold true for full faculty). Work/Life balance is weird... some work 9-5 on the dot, others live like it's a startup. Know your position's expectations ahead of time. Leaving the academic bubble is shocking... finding out that tech is 10 years behind where you thought it was and trying to communicate your expectations for commercial technology is tough. Tech Transfer has an "East Coast" mentality to licensing IP to startups. You may be founding a company in the SF Bay Area, but CMU is going to act like you're in Boston.

review_title: CMU wonderful place, publish or perish
pros: Carnegie Mellon University is a wonderful place to work, at least inside of the School of Computer Science. The university is essentially organized as a large collection of independent units (at the campus, college, and department level). Problems in one department or college has very little effect elsewhere. The place has a very entrepreneurial flavor and the broadest range of activity of any organization that does Computer Science research.
cons:
For the administrative staff, I think it is a wonderful place to work, as long as you can deal with the occasional egomaniac professor. They don't have great social skills.

For the technical staff, it just isn't clear why you would work at CMU. The opportunity cost is very high. The best counter to problem is to get another degree while at CMU. CMU benefits cover about 60% of the cost.

For research, you're at one of the centers of the world, so things are good. Just make sure you get the grant money. Everything else (students, publications, tenure, start-ups etc.) flows from that.

review_title: Summer IS interns at Carnegie Mellon University
pros: The opportunities to take classes at this amazing institution. I was a summer intern at CMU and I learned a lot! I picked up lots of technical skills including generating html pages, working with CSS and learning all about databases.  I didn't know I could learn soo much in just 6 weeks! I worked with clients, creating numerous presentations, talking to them to determine their needs, worked with project management, learned about team dynamics. It was a very rewarding experience with excellent faculty members waiting to assist you with problems and questions. I learned invaluable lessons that I will never forget.
cons: I worked for a six-week internship so there wasn't a lot of time to get things done. Since they paid us upfront, a lot of my team members were not motivated to complete the work. The work / life balance was really off. There were nights when there wasn't time to sleep, and there was never a day when the work load was light. You learn alot, but since it is packed into such a short time there is no time to really explore the city or do a lot of fun things. They did take us on some trips, however, so overall it was worth it.

review_title: Very decent to work at Carnegie Mellon
pros:
Carnegie Mellon University is a very solid place to work - there are perks such as free gym pass and gym classes, opportunities to take on CMU classes (I worked my way through my masters), and a bus pass. Plus! You get stretches of vacation days because it's a university. 

Much better to work here than at University of PIttsburgh (does not pay well, no matter what department you are in) - particularly if you work in the computer science department, where there are more opportunities for salary negotiation. You are surrounded by very intelligent people, so there's always projects to see and talks to go to. It's a great place to network. The 401k match is excellent - around 8%.
cons: It really depends on what department you are in - culture can change really rapidly on this. I was in a department that was fun because it was a bit like a start up, but it was also tricky because management was all over the place and sticking to a plan rarely happened.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
The people/supervisor(s) you work with are very understanding and helpful. They will do their best to accommodate your concerns and taking your suggestions into consideration, unlike other places.

Even if there is too much workload, people will be considerate (especially if you're taking some heavyweight Computer Science/Electrical Engineering courses) and will try to adjust the established deadlines to better suit your needs.

Needless to mention you would be working with some of the greatest minds and rare talents, be it any field of this University.
cons:
The only con I could mention of in here is with regard to an isolated issue I experienced with one particular supervisor who was 'very' unethical in her ways. 
But then again this is just about one person and statistically speaking, these examples exist everywhere. In short, it is a great place to work at and you will have a very rewarding and an astute learning experience.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: There are tons of interesting research projects going on at CMU. Campus is rather small, so it's fairly easy to run into somebody you know, or attend a talk from another discipline--and there are lots of interesting seminars here. CMU has a lot of interdisciplinary research centers, and I think it's fairly easy at the individual level to forge interdisciplinary collaborations.
cons: Food options on campus are disappointing, though great campus coffee spots and the proximity to Oakland mitigates this somewhat. It can be hard to find a place to sit in the common areas (the coffee shops and libraries are always packed) if you want to get out of the office for a bit.

review_title: Like working for a Silicon Valley/Seattle company, but for a bit less
pros:
Great Benefits: In addition to the usual health insurance and retirement plans, campus facilities and resources are also available to staff such as the gym/athletics fields, computer clusters/library/internet and also the ability to audit classes.
Personal Time Off: Generally more flexible than other companies with requesting time off, after working for awhile you get 18 PTO days, on top of days off granted for usual holidays such as Thanksgiving, Christmas/New Years, Memorial Day, Independence Day.
cons:
Low Salary Pay and Increments: While pay is competitive within the region for similar education level and technical jobs, compensation overall is much lower than what's accepted as standard in the field. You should also expect your salary increases to match inflation for good performance, and no 'bonuses' or other types of additional compensation.
Irregular and increased hours near semester ends: Generally as projects get closer to deadlines, it becomes a lot harder to get PTO requests and flexibility honoured, though generally afterwards it becomes easier.

pros: I have learned a lot, many classes covering many disciplines, school is the main priority and everyone is smart and loves to learn.
cons: No school spirit, teachers can be very good or very bad, people are spread too thin and everyone is stressed, least fun school ever, food is absolutely horrible, not very flexible when you want to switch majors, there is a support system but it is not good (health services included its horrible), easy to get left behind in classes, cultivates bad GPAs, needs a better rep for amount of work students put in. To sum it up I would never ever send my child here or donate a single penny to this school, the few positives are instantly negated because this place is ridiculously depressing, go here if you dont like having fun and only want to stress about school.

review_title: CMU A good lace to work to get a free or near free education in a world class university
pros:
Flexible Time off policy.
Good 403b plan.
Close to home.
Good tuition benefits for employees and eligible children.
Relaxed atmosphere.
Casual dress is allowed
cons: Currently the university is like working for corporate without any of the benefits.  There are no incentives to excel at your job.  There is no room for movement into new positions.  Communication within the university is OK.  The university recently lost a lot of money due to poor decisions and no one was punished for losing over $24 Million.  There is a wage and hiring freeze along with a promotion freeze.  During this time the university spent $25 Million on a piece of property for future building.  Read Dilbert and you will understand.  I lived through this in the early 2000's at a tech company.

pros: Carnegie Mellon is a special place - there is probably no other University like it in terms of creativity, innovation, interdisciplinary, and the dedication of the people who work and study there.  It's the kind of place many places try to be but just cant because it isn't part of the culture.  If you get the opportunity to work there, you should do it!  Each college is different, but at the Heinz College, they care about their employees, supportive of entrepreneurial efforts and work to get people into places where they can do their best work.
cons: Staff salaries are competitive, but VERY low annual percentage increases - typical 1-2 % which doesn't keep up with the true increased cost of living.  Healthcare plan is outrageously priced.

review_title: Challenging work, smart people, great benefits
pros: At Carnegie Mellon you are surrounded by lots of smart people.  The benefits packages are strong; most groups offer a generous/practical work/life balance to their staffers.  It's nice to be surrounded by students; you pick up on their energy, enthusiasm, and optimism.  In terms of the broader community, Pittsburgh itself is alternately the nation's smallest big city of biggest small town, which thing is charming and annoying by turns.
cons: Carnegie Mellon is a good place to work.  As a result, people, there tends to be relatively low turnover.  The result is that career options are surprisingly limited.  Note that pay is not always on par with industry.

pros: The structure of the coursework is great and efficient. The content of the course is practical and close to the industry, so I learned a lot about the technology applied in practice. The culture of CMU is just like its motto, my heart is in the work, so you will have a lot of hardworking classmates. It's a great experience to learn in CMU.
cons: The work load in CMU is large. Since all the students are the top students in their previous school before CMU, there is a lot of peer pressure. Almost all the courses have a considerable large amount of homework. Therefore, it is essential to learn how to deal with pressure in CMU.

job_title: Grad Student/Research Engineer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
* Filled with extremely smart people

* For the most part, very friendly community.  You are part of a family.  

* Above-average benefits.

* Lots of opportunities for personal growth
cons:
* Salaries.  A lot of people continue to work there after grad school and don't know any better, so they can get away with paying crap salaries.

* Bureaucracy.  Not yet as bad as a public university but increasing rapidly.

* Like any university, individual personalities have a lot to do with setting the tone for a job, so while most people (faculty, management)  are good folks, there are a few rotten eggs and if you worked for one of them your job might suck.

* Rat race.  Faculty and senior researcher staff work ridiculous hours and receive minimal support from above - they are mostly on their own to bring in money to support themselves and their staff/students.  It's good and bad - lots of freedom.

review_title: Insanely fun job, relatively low pay.
pros: Every day at work is a blast. Very exciting work, lots of smart people. Interesting challenges and a quality of work that can't be found anywhere else in the world. Don't underestimate this because it vastly outweighs the cons below.
cons:
Because it is in the education field pay is lower than a comparable industry job. There are also no bonuses, and it is difficult to advance without an advanced degree.

Very few windows to the outside. It is possible to go a whole day without knowing what the weather was like.

pros: This job has some pros such as flexible work hour, generous rate. Also it is a good opportunity for training teaching skills because TA has to lead review session every week. In this review session, TA can discuss what students have learned during the class as well as advanced issues.
cons: Mandatory work loads are not an easy job. Grading homework, holding office hour (2~3 hours per week), and communication with students are sometimes burdensome. Especially, ordinary classes at CMU have over 10 homework throughout the semester, TA should grade homework every week, and return them to students in a timely manner. It might be not an easy task.

review_title: Brilliant minds on one end self important elitists on the other end
pros: This is a great place to go if you or someone in your family wants to further their education. They have a good tuition reimbursement program and decent learning and development programs. They just revamped their HR department to respond to employee needs.
cons: The constant bureaucracy and politics that keep ineffective, racist managers and staff members in control can be difficult to get used to.  Witnessing those with less experience and knowledge get promoted above and/or making more money than others simply because of the color of their skin is a sad thing to see in this day and age. Unfortunately, it is the Pittsburgh way. That coupled with slim to no promoting from within (unless you know someone).

review_title: Carnegie Mellon is an inspiring place to be
pros:
Lively academic environment. Wonderful easy-going place to live. Good compensation for the cost of living in Pittsburgh. Cutting edge research.
Cross-disciplinary projects are very common and extremely successful.
cons:
Some departments suffer from bad management making it hard to work for positive change.
All in all, good people who mean well, but not always the best leaders or managers.
Graduate students are at the mercy of their advisers and professors who are not given clear instructions what their responsibilities towards the students entail. This sometimes leads to unproductive micromanagement.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Obviously, the experience is highly dependent on your academic advisor. The ECE stipend is fairly generous. CMU classes are generally very well taught. I worked on research funded by DARPA; the research work at CMU, in general, is state-of-the-art. You'll meet some of the smartest people on earth.
cons: My office was disgusting, dirty, and the building was infested with roaches. I know we're just grad students, but the work environment was practically unacceptable. I typically would work from home, coffee shops, etc. There aren't many good places to eat on campus. My lab was small (only 3 students), so this detracted from the social experience of grad student life, but again, this depends on one's advisor.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The people and management are easy to talk to and know a lot about the structure of their department. I work in the Housing and Dining Services sector of the university. I like working with my immediate supervisors. They are helpful and informative.
cons: The software used in the housing department seems outdated. In times of room selection or opening day in the beginning of the academic year, the systems do not work as smoothly as they can. Being a high tech school, there should be a better locking system. The pay for students is also rather low.

pros: Astronomy and biophysics groups are growing, and it is expected that the condensed matter group will reach a high level as well. There is also access to many of the other departmental classes and resources. For example, several students leave with experience in machine learning from the computer science department.
cons: The physics department suffers a bit from self-governance. It is not uncommon for many student requirements to slip by unnoticed until it compounds to a larger issue.  Additionally, the high-energy theory group seems to be falling apart.

review_title: Great place to do your doctoral work if you have a good idea of the research you would like to conduct.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: CMU is one of the best universities in the country for my field. You will not find better professors, and they give you all of the freedom you need to do your own work. Most people in tech fields recognize CMU, and many give special attention to people with a diploma from this university.
cons: From day one, funding is highly tied to the professor with whom you work. This means there is little possibility to explore, as there is at other programs, so if you come to the program without knowing what exactly you want to do, it can be difficult if you would like to change paths.

review_title: Alright but could be a lot better
pros: Meet a lot of people - some of which will rule the world.
cons:
Resident assistant salary doesn't even cover housing. RA is paid with salary, rather than discounted from the housing fee, so even though it looks like it covers 3/4 of the housing fee, after taxes it covers a lot less.

A lot of fellow RAs are pretentious about how they think you should do your job, instead of focusing on the  point of helping freshmen adjust to college life. Supervisors will tell you to "be a good RA" but actually mean they want you to spend your whole semester changing the decorations in the halls.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: CMU has an enormous presence in Computer Science, having not just a CS department, but a whole School of Computer Science having multiple departments dedicated to various disciplines within the field, e.g. Language Technologies Institute, Human Computer Interaction Institute, Machine Learning Department, Robotics Institute, Software Engineering Institute, ...
cons: It's large enough that you might get lost unless you really shine. There are a lot of bright and highly motivated grad students here. If you arrive, be expected to work hard and learn from peers.

review_title: CMU Embraces Employees & Strong Work Ethic
pros: I love working at CMU! I have always worked in higher ed, but CMU is very unique in that it strongly and openly values employees and embraces them as part of their mission. They appreciate different ideas and opinions, new ways of working, creativity - innovation at any level. There are a lot of opportunities for growth in positions as well as eventually transitioning to new departments, locations, etc.
cons: I do not get paid as much as I would if I worked somewhere corporate/for-profit. I also do not have a lot of opportunity to work off-campus or from home since most business takes place during certain hours on campus.

review_title: Good work by staff is rarely praised, acknowledged, or rewarded, making it hard to keep up the good work.
pros: The students are very engaging. HR offers good programming for self-assessment and betterment. Salary is good when compared to neighboring universities. Most faculty are invested in students (including the undergraduate level), making the staff members' jobs easier.
cons: Benefits package is not as good as neighboring universities, particularly paid time off. There is almost no room for promotion in staff positions. Overachievers will get frustrated easily under these conditions. It's true that at many schools, staff without PhDs are treated somewhat differently than those with PhDs, but that is particularly true at CMU. If you do not have a PhD, it is unlikely that you will be given a strong leadership position in the org chart - no matter your experience.

review_title: CMU's School of Computer Science ROCKS!
pros: School of Computer Science is a great place to work. World-leader in CS academics; great people and projects; very cool environment. The educational opportunities are stellar. Benefits are good. Equipment and facilities are outstanding.  Find the right project to work for, and you can be very very happy. Cutting-edge research projects in most areas of computer science, robotics, software engineering, etc. Great place to be, especially if you want to publish a lot.
cons: Staff salaries are on the low side, especially compared with industry. Academic environment doesn't understand how to evaluate industrial experience. It is difficult to find projects with actual users (if that's an issue that matters to you). If you're into shipping product, you don't want to work at a university.

review_title: Very Comfortable Place to Work, Reasonable People
pros: Here at Carnegie Mellon University, it is rather easy to get a research position in a moderately interesting field, and you make pretty good money compared to other jobs that college students can get into. It gets you good experience for a real career in the corporate or university world.
cons: You cannot get much of a promotion, beyond the $0.50 per year raise. All professors have agreed upon a set rate of payment. There are high expectations of performance.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: There are a wide variety of people who see problems differently and who can help you develop very broad skills and grow as a professional. The professors are very knowledgeable and open with their students. Working at CMU is a great opportunity to learn and find what you are really interested in.
cons: You have to work really hard. If you love what you do, that's not really so bad. However, it isn't all roses. There are high expectations for CMU grad students, and they are closely monitored to ensure adequate progress

review_title: CMU is a great environment to work in
job_title: Senior Systems Scientist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The people at CMU are friendly and collaborative.  Working as a faculty member at CMU is one of the most rewarding experiences. All the faculty keep their doors open and it is easy to work together with anyone.
cons: The biggest downside to working in academia is that the pay is not as high as comparable jobs in industry.  Also, the hours tend to be rather long.  A friend of mine said "As a professor, I have great freedom.  I get to work any 80 hours a week that I want to."

job_title: Senior Academic Coordinator in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Can take classes for free, many highly intelligent people work here, many resources for training, encouraged to continue education, library access
cons: Some departments never promote from within, some colleges on campus seem very poor (money-wise) and others seem to have more money to spend. Over long periods of time, salary tends to stagnate and not keep up with inflation (at least in my area).

review_title: A great place to do research in Computer Science & Engineering
pros:
CMU is Top 1 in Computer Science and Top 4 in Computer Engineering.
There are great professors and they are always thinking out of box. That's why there are always brand new ideas coming out of here.
Peers here are extraordinarily smart and hard working. Usually you learn a lot from peers.
There are various assistance helping International students to develop their career including English courses, free services and tutoring in academic writing, preparation of presentation, job application, etc.
Gym and swimming pool are fantastic.
cons:
Everyone works so hard so it is very stressful.
There are no good cantine on campus. 
Apartments around are so expensive and you may have to share with other students.
Course workload is extremely high.

pros: Very flexible hours!  You get to decide what times are best for you and Carnegie Mellon's Housing Department will try to accommodate to you as much as possible.
cons: The pay is somewhat low.  Perhaps because it is in Pittsburgh, the minimum wage is $7.35 but $9,00 for graveyard shifts.  If you work during the holidays like Thanksgiving or Christmas then they pa you $15 an hour.  Other than that the pay in my opinion is low.

review_title: Cool work, but severely underpaid and required work outside of expertise
pros: The project and the work that I was doing was really cool and interesting!
cons: The amount I was paid was severely below my value. I was asked to do a large amount of work outside of my expertise, which took a long time and was incredibly frustrating. I had very little feedback from my supervisor that would improve my skills. Forced to sit through long, tedious, unrelated lab meetings. The HR people I dealt with seemed like they were annoyed with my existence and were uninterested in helping me out.

pros: I feel like I work with an amazing group of people. They are not just my co-workers, they are also my friends. I am not afraid to come into the office every day, and in fact look forward to seeing everyone!
cons: The work I am currently doing is very mind-numbing. It has gotten so bad during the summer that I have considered looking for a new job because I just can't stand coming in to do mostly nothing.

review_title: Excellent Facilities for Research and friendly community
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Mountain View, CA
pros:
1. World class research facilities and faculty
2. Great place to boost your career
cons:
1. Be prepared for lots of work - and ready to forget work-life balance :).
2. Non-software classes in Silicon Valley campus are scarce.

review_title: Nice, fair work, but very low pay
job_title: Andrew Ambassador, Athletics Desk Attendant, Lifeguard, Concert Usher in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I worked multiple Carnegie Mellon student jobs when I was there as an undergraduate. I had a pretty great time at every job. You get to work with other students, which is really great for networking and making friends. The supervisors are super nice and understand that you are basically only working to make a few extra bucks while studying.
cons: The pay is generally very low for the type of work you do. Pennsylvania has a very very low minimum and you get that minimum wage for many jobs that normally pay more (for instance, Andrew Ambassador, which is basically campus tours, pays minimum, whereas at UPitt right down the street they pay much higher).

review_title: CMU Senior Research Programmer, Computer Science dept.
job_title: Senior Research Programmer in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Dynamic, fast-paced, challenging environment. Lots of cultural diversity. Laid-back campus atmosphere. Always learning new things. Good benefits.
cons: Salary is about half industry. New hires get paid at rates that exceed that achieved by long term employees who have had cumulative raises. In other words, experience is punished. "new-ness" is rewarded

review_title: I've really enjoyed my graduate school experience here at CMU, and will definitely remember it fondly after I graduate.
pros: Great support system for grad students, tremendous focus in inter-departmental collaborations and building towards IPs. There is also a real focus on career opportunities following the completion of your graduate degree. Also, the compensation is right in line (or above) comparable institutions and with the affordable living expenses in Pittsburgh, it can go a long way.
cons: The campus is expanding to different areas of Pittsburgh, so depending on your department/job, you may be on a satellite campus.

review_title: Fair wage, lots of flexibility, great place to build experience.
pros: The pay is good. The time is flexible and entirely works around on your schedule. The other staff and the students who come in are nice, so there is not much hardship dealing with them.
cons: The program doesn't have much increase in terms of wage, and sometimes the work you do is a bit underpaid. However, you are really not trying to make a living off here. Students may much more for tuition and other stuff at this college.

pros: Rewarding work, good benefits. As research staff, you work with some of the most brilliant researchers in the world.  The work is fascinating and pushes you to learn.
cons: There is nothing in place to help research staff when funding is interrupted or terminated. This instills a sense of no matter how loyal you have been, they don't care. In most departments, the emphasis is on funding students.  It would help if there was some sort of office that directs displaced employees to find positions other than being thrown into the same basket with everyone else applying for jobs.

pros:
- Highly driven individuals
- Great professors, who are genuinely invested in the success of their students
- Standard, but accessible, network of advisors and academic resources
- Best Computer Science courses in the nation
cons:
- Workload can be highly burdening and borders on unmanageable in some of the CS classes
- High departmental barriers in terms of changing/adding majors, especially in computer science (i.e. CMU is really only for students who know their career goals and major plans prior to enrolling)

review_title: Great place to work but need to play the game
pros: great benefits. Great amount of paid time off, great people to work with. They want you to succeed. Encourage you to continue your education. The hours are good. Some positions are more flexible then others. Easy to stay forever.
cons: Have to play the politics game really to move up. The hiring process in very slow moving . depending on where you are you might be doing a lot and working on a lot of things but you feel like a jack of all trades master of none.  Pay is lower then same positions in public sector.

review_title: Good mix of technology and work - life balance
pros: I've worked in higher ed for over 20 years and CMU is like no other employer I ever worked. So much energy and willingness to solve problems. Communications great in and between teams. At CMU, they strive to lead the way for others. Management supportive of career development and those at the top make it a point to know what you are working on and want input how to assist. Hard work is rewarded.
cons: Very dynamic, sometimes hard to keep up with the pace. If looking for something that remains static, don't apply.

pros: CMU is very famous for IT and Data courses! I think it is the best place for computer science guys!
cons: Well, CMU is definitely not for social science and humanities students. The reason is simple: although you will have the chance to get exposed to great IT skills, you won't have great opportunities for your own major. Almost everything here is about Big Data or Robotics. You won't learn much about policies, economics or other social science

review_title: Staff: how you feel about it depends on what you're allergic to.
pros: There are always a lot of interesting things going on, with University projects, University/NASA partnerships, and University/business partnerships presenting considerable opportunities for networking.  The prestige of the University regularly attracts high quality guest speakers, and location has its own appeal, being in the Shenandoah Plaza Historic District in the NASA Research Park at NASA-Ames.
cons: There is always a wide gulf between the non-academic staff and the academic staff which you'll only notice if you're staff. Recent instability at the top of both the academic and staff director hierarchy have seemed to amplify a sense of insecurity in the staff positions.

pros: Flexible hours, and decent pay comparable to similar teaching assistant positions. Additionally, being given the opportunity to teach students helps reinforce my own knowledge, which is great for when it comes time for my technical interviews. Having SCS TA on your resume is great in and of itself, but the real benefits come from the opportunity to work more closely with professors who have valuable industry contacts.
cons: Dealing with students can be frustrating at times, and I would like the payroll system to make deposits more frequently than once every two weeks. Also, professors are often unorganized with their course material, so it becomes your job to fix that.

pros: Great courses. Great research opportunities. The tepper school of business has a history of producing extremely successful leaders in academia.
cons: Carnegie Mellon University will have a transformative impact on society through continual innovation in education, research, creativity, and entrepreneurship.

review_title: CASOS is a great, laid back place to work in a growing college campus community.
pros: Very intelligent coworkers who know a great deal about the work they do and are passionate about it.  The management is cohesive and knows how to work together with their employees.
cons: Being on a campus community and due to the nature of the work involved, it may be very difficult to get a job there. It is definitely more geared towards those in the CMU community.

review_title: This job is what you make it
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Depends on your department. Flexibility, interesting co-workers, and a great location for a young family. For engineers and computer science practitioners this is one of the world's top universities, and they are used to interdisciplinary collaboration, since they've been doing it longer than most other places that are just getting into the game.
cons: Many specific research areas lack real cooperative teamwork like that at most corporate positions, although this is common to most of academia. What's really annoying is that most people think they are great at it, when it is only true in relation to other highly competitive academic environments.

review_title: Good place to work with some good people
pros: I am in the chemistry department, the atmosphere is mostly friendly with a lot of support and collaboration.
cons: A few of the faculty members have large intellectual egos and do not like to be questioned in any way.  There is no recourse as a graduate student if they dislike you and try to get you out of their group based solely on their personal reasons.  I am not the only person who this has happened to, and most people do not get a chance in another group after their adviser decides they do not like you

pros: Great place to start as junior faculty member, very supportive of career advancement, very creative and collaborative environment
cons: Not a lot of feedback unless you seek it out, doesn't seem great in terms of keeping up with market salaries as you move up in rank, recognition of contributions to organization not provided as much as recognition of external accomplishments (i.e. publications)

pros: Carnegie Mellon University is good at a lot of fields, but what it excels at most are the intersections of these fields. For example as good as Carnegie Mellon University is at computer science and design, it is arguably even better at Human-Computer Interaction where it combines the two.
cons: Big stress culture, people tend to add a lot of stress to the work they do. Pittsburgh takes a lot of getting used to, the weather is highly volatile. Not too much to do around campus and not many attractive employment opportunities around either.

review_title: A good place for research, esp. interdisciplinary research
pros: A very small school so every department works closely. Lots of research centers which involve research efforts across multiple departments. Very smart faculties. Very computer science focused (a good thing in the current generation). Very affordable living cost in Pittsburgh.
cons: Library has really limited resource. I have to ask friends from other universities to download papers for me. Pittsburgh is a relatively dull city and some faculty members leave for other places now and then. And Carnegie Mellon is notorious for long working hours.

review_title: Cool place for postdoctoral, if you can find a good group
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The city is nice. Living cost is relatively low. Salary is (slightly) above national average (biological sciences). I really do not have much to say about the postdoc experience, as it is directly related to the group/lab, instead of the university.
cons: The place (Mellon Institute) I work is kind of depressing. Mellon Institute, hosting dept of chemistry and biology,  is outside of the main campus.  I really do not have much to say about the postdoc experience, as it is directly related to the group/lab, instead of the university.

job_title: Summer Researcher and Software Developer in Pitts, PA
pros: The computer science department encapsulates a wonderful work environment full of compassionate and motivated people who ultimately love what they do and it shows. Diligence  is contagious and collaboration is promoted. Fellow colleagues have an open door policy and the the motto is "Forward and onwards together".
cons: It's difficult to come up with any cons about Carnegie Mellon University, it truly is one of the top computer science institutions in the Nation.

pros:
World-renowned institution, with numerous programs that are frequently ranked among the best in the world.
Strong interdisciplinary program enabling student to develop imaginative solutions to problems
Cutting-edge research and technology
High achieving, energetic - yet approachable - faculty
Innovative and flexible curriculum
Top 10 program ratings
Collegial, supportive and respectful climate
Great student/faculty ratio for personal attention
Successful alumni with sustaining departmental involvement
Beautiful campus, great resources, located in dynamic city of Pittsburgh
Incredibly bright, talented and motivated student population
cons: Economic changes effecting the way we work

pros: Carnegie Mellon is very family oriented.  There is a lot of opportunity to take on new tasks and new projects.  You have a lot of autonomy.  The benefits are good - 3 weeks PTO/year to start plus 12 paid days off.  8% contribution to 403(b). Limited free tuition for employees and dependents.
cons:
There is a distinct hierarchy - faculty - staff - students.  Faculty have their own hierarchy and most give little respect to junior faculty not on a tenure track. While not universally true, many faculty are arrogant, rude, overly demanding, and treat staff as though they are idiots.  This can make for a hostile work environment for the staff.  The pay is horribly low and employment is not guaranteed. Raises are normally below the cost of living, although you can argue for a merit increase.

Rather than publish or perish, it's get funded or get out the door. This is true for both faculty and staff who are on soft money.  Individuals are responsible for finding their own funding.  Complicating matters - the overhead rate is close to 60% make it difficult to justify seeking out smaller, more easily won grants.  However, like many other universities, the size of the administration grows and grows.

While the vast majority of individuals are dedicated and incredibly hardworking, there are many who are doing just what they need to do to get by.   

Hiring is often done externally and promotion from within is rare.

pros: One can gain plenty of knowledge, research experience, and meet the greatest minds in one of the world's greatest engineering institutions in the world.
cons: It takes time to grow at such a large university. Potential for economic growth is also limited. Research work can be hard at time and very challenging and can be both mentally and physically consuming.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Teaching staff are well respected in the CMU community. 
It is a great addition for any resume. 
Professors are usually easy to work with and seem to care about their students.
cons:
Pay for certain undergraduate positions is a bit lacking for the density of work. 
Not a huge community effort on improving the skills on the teaching staff, despite the events the administration attempts to hold.

pros:
Prestigious academic environment
Full time benefits are good
Free public transit
cons:
Silo mentality, no one knows what anyone else is actually doing, communication is terrible among departments
Part-time benefits are absolutely awful. Expect to pay double the full-time rate for health insurance (family coverage costs me over $800/mo), no options for dental or vision. 
Hourly part time pay is insulting
Parking is limited and ridiculously expensive

job_title: Technical Operations Manager in West Pittsburg, PA
pros: Allows a more flexibility due to non-corporate environment. Good opportunity to learn and practice. Academic environment is full with really well educated and nice people.
cons: Low wages, cheap equipment and hardware, lack of standards due to a big number of various research groups demanding different things.

review_title: Great benefits and people but job can be boring
pros:
The benefits are great.  Started out with four weeks of vacation and great health care.
I really enjoyed the staff I worked with, they were always positive and had a good time.  It was a great place to work.
cons:
Limited growth opportunities.  There was not a lot of potential to move up as the hierarchy at the staff level is pretty minimal.

Work could get very slow during certain periods of the year and the day would drag.  Was not my cup of tea.

review_title: Great while it lasted. Work Study.
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: I worked in the grad school at Heinz. Very easy to work around my class schedule and tests. Very understanding boss. Coworkers were great.
cons: Didn't have any. I wish I had worked their sooner. The only con was probably the fact that towards the end of my time there, there was construction being done. Went back to visit and the improvements were great.

pros:
Personal Access to stellar faculty (especially David Kosbie and David Anderson).  You get to teach two recitations a week so if teaching is your thing you get a ton of practice with it.
The staff is one of the smartest and nicest staffs that I've ever been a part of so that's an incredible special experience!
cons: It's a lot of work for a part-time student job. I was working nearly 20 hrs a week all semester while trying to juggle a hard CS semester so I was swamped. But totally worth it!

pros: There are so many possibilities here at CMU. Great benefits package, they are an equal opportunity employer, and the people are great to work with.
cons: Professional Development is not encouraged enough. Staff should be given the same opportunities to take classes as students and not have to register last. Academic programs of study should be offered in the evening too.

review_title: The Work Aspect (Teaching) Is Pretty Good in the English Department
pros: You are a full instructor (Instructor of Record) for all courses, have the opportunity to teach advanced courses, receive a lot of support, and get to teach some of the smartest young people in the world.
cons: You're a grad student, and the teaching salary (stipend they call it) is fine, but you have to do a ton of other work that is not compensated.

job_title: Research Assistant in Moffett Field, CA
pros: The campus is on a great and safe location on the Moffett Field airbase. The professors here are all lots of fun and the amount of work required was reasonable. If you aren't a student yet this is a great opportunity to meet and open the door to a potential graduate degree down the line.
cons: As a research assistant you only make 15 dollars an hour, which is really low compared to any other internship you could acquire. During the summer the campus is especially quiet, with some students only coming for night classes.

pros: Excellent pay, decent healthcare benefits, annual raises, 15+ days PTO in your first year of service, 8% contribution to your retirement plan even if you don't contribute anything.  Work life balance is important to management. Overall, the best organization I've ever worked for. I work for the Tepper School of Business and the Dean remembers my name.  I work a low-level desk job and he treats me with the same respect he does senior management.
cons: Nowhere to park that doesn't cost BIG BUCKS

review_title: Great academics and education, but poor benefits
job_title: Ph D Student in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: World-class education.  Especially in computer science.  The choices are almost unlimited.  Nicely organized events for my graduate program.   Bus transportation is nice around the local universities.
cons: Health benefits are far worse than a previous state school I was a graduate student at.  Parking costs can be around $1,000 a year if you want to live off campus in a nice area for a dog and/or family.  Wireless internet -- pretty much the only option for most students is very slow.

job_title: Software Development Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
I was a programmer developing software that was to be used for various research purpouses by Professors, graduate students and post-docs.

Great environment, intelligent people, interesting projects, laid-back yet dynamic evironment.
cons: At least in my department, I saw a lack of desire to improve the software we were working on and too much focus on endless, impractical features that were desired by the researchers.

review_title: Resident Assistant: Great job for those who put in the effort
pros: good leadership experience, great bosses, good personal experience, provide living arrangement, good source of  connection for the campus. A perfect student job
cons: The student boss, CA, are sometimes poorly trained. There is a huge gap in skill and commitment between RAs and some of them are not properly trained and should be fired. Others do not work on a team well and should not be hired. Low Pay

review_title: The most ignorant people I have ever worked with.
pros: None.  This place is full of egomaniacal jerks who don't know how to treat people.
cons: Unbelievably ignorant people.  Heavy work loads.  Management is clueless.  I interviewed for a job, was called and told the job was mine, I started working there, and then found out they were still interviewing other people for my job and that I had to interview AGAIN for it.  These people are liars of epic proportion.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Good school with decent funding. Stipend for PhD students better than average. City has a relatively low cost of living.
cons: Like all PhD programs, your experience depends on your advisor. I did not have the best time, but perhaps others who are a better fit will. This is likely true for most PhD programs elsewhere as well.

review_title: Carnegie Mellon University is a great place to work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: People at CMU are very open and collaborative.  They take research and undergraduate teaching very seriously, but they also recognize the importance of having a balanced lifestyle.
cons: The only real challenge of working at CMU is that you have to be serious and passionate about your work.  If not, you won't succeed here.

review_title: Pittsburgh is Great!  This review is not department/program-specific.
pros:
-  CMU is a top notch school
-  Pittsburgh rules
-  Pittsburgh is not as bad as you think it is
-  Seriously it's not.  It used to be super polluted and majorly run-down, but now it's really nice and not polluted at all.
-  Lots of cool restaurants and small breweries and cool neighborhoods
-  Cheap rent!
- "Seasons"!
cons: Genuinely no cons.  If you're gonna do grad school, CMU, in Pittsburgh, is a fantastic place to go.

pros: During my time as a professional fundraiser for Carnegie Mellon I learned valuable sales tactics while also being able to work through college through the work study program.
cons: The pay isn't that great although it is better than other Campos jobs at 10.45 instead of 7.50. The job is hard and pretty boring as you can be on the phones for like 3 hours straight

review_title: Its a really good school to work for
pros: Many different types of jobs to choose from, benefits with most staff or faculty jobs, great pay for students, nice people, great atmosphere
cons: Its a lot of work, but Its a great school so people are expected to work hard.  Your expected to go a little above and beyond which can be a bit much sometimes, especially since you usually have a lot of work.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Strong culture of innovation and very close to the pittsburgh city center. The umpteem number of development programs help both students and employees gain professional expertise.
cons: As with any other university, the salary is low. Also parking is a huge issue. The flip side of being close to the city means there is very little parking space available.

pros: I loved being at the school, learning about a variety of new technologies and working with great colleagues.
cons: I enjoyed the weather overall but it was very cold and gray, some of the architecture is odd and the neighborhoods are all spread out.

job_title: Administrative Coordinator I in Pitts, PA
pros: Working with dynamic and creative people. World renowned institution. Excellent, up-To-date technology. Opportunity for growth. The facilities are state-of-the-art. Emphasis on collaboration.
cons: It is all about the department manager. I worked for a micromanager who placed more emphasis on the process of TQM than the goals and big picture.

review_title: CMU is one of the most prestige engineering school in the US with all access to the pioneers of high-tech industry.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Lots of interdisciplinary research going on here. Ideas flow very fast in the compact environment, also Pittsburgh is a nice place to live.
cons: Lack of business environment, lack of high-tech companies surrounding. Mainly a tech school with not many culture events all over the year.

pros: The structure at CMU is horizontal, which means that almost everyone there is approachable and friendly. The time off is generous, and schedules usually mirror those of the students. Professors also take plenty of time off, which means that when they're on holiday the workload slows down significantly.
cons: It can be frustrating to deal with university politics, and the HR department is rather slow at getting things done. It took some time to get paychecks started and unused vacation days to be redeemed.

pros: The people are so nice to work with. The hours are flexible and HR seems to really care for the employee.
cons: Raises are low, not really encouraged to do Professional Development, and most classes are during the day and it's hard to use the paid tuition benefit.

review_title: The Entertainment Technology Center is a great place to work
pros:
+Opportunities to work with various new and exciting technologies
+Opportunities to network
+Opportunities to build up a portfolio by working on team projects
+Chances to possibly visit other ETC campuses (global)
+Amazing people to work and socialize with
+BVW parties are always a lot of fun
cons:
-Approaching deadlines may cause a lot of stress (probably typical anywhere, though)
-Pay isn't the greatest
-You may be thrown in the deep end and go above and beyond your job responsibilities
-Pittsburgh isn't exactly the sunniest of cities

pros: Teaching students the material is fulfilling, and helps me to be more aware of how to communicate to others and explain things in different ways to cater to different learning styles.
cons: I have been working for over half of the semester and I am still not set up with payroll.  Grading exams is very time consuming, and inconvenient during weeks with other coursework.

pros:
- Very friendly coworkers and advisors
- Collaborative research
- Generally well-funded
- Significant freedom to choose the project you work on or propose a new project
cons:
-  Long hours (typically 60 hr weeks)
-  Average grad student salary
-  No parking (but free bus passes)
-  The undergrads you teach are typically book-smart, but lacking in common sense

job_title: Facilities Architect & Project Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Exciting place.  Everything Academic is cutting edge. Good perks and benefits.
If you are an academic it's great. For Staff.... Perks and bene's still good. Lots of interesting things going on.
cons:
Not as great for staff. 18 yrs as a Facilities Architect & Project Manager. High stress, demanding. Half the department was "downsized", mostly older workers. By a year later, most were replaced with young inexperienced (cheaper) workers. 
Still, if you can handle it, go for it.

review_title: The best computer science program in the world
pros: The School of Computer Science is ranked number one in the world. The faculty is near or at the top of their field in so many areas: machine learning, robotics, systems, networking, computational biology, verification and programming languages. The character and achievements of the faculty draw similarly brilliant and committed students. There is also the possibility to develop very different skills to a very high level.
cons: Extremely demanding environment. Expectation from students, postdoc and faculty members is really high.

job_title: Student Research Intern in Moffett Field, CA
pros: Research intern gives undergraduate student a great chance to put what we have learned into practice. We can follow our interest to set up projects and get advice from advisor. And you also get paid.
cons: Sometimes you can be really busy and have to work extra hours, but I actually don't think this to be bad. The more busy you are, the more you can get from the internship.

review_title: Came here nine years ago for a brief sabbatical, found it was a great place to be part of, been part of it since.
job_title: Associate Teaching Professor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Bright students and colleagues, innovative and entrepreneurial culture, willingness to try new and unproven ideas in education and research. It's a bit like working at Hogwarts some days.
cons: We move and make decisions quickly for a university, but that's still a much slower pace of action than you might find in a modern for-profit company.

review_title: Easy to get a job if you look for them
pros: I have had several positions in Carnegie Mellon and they have all been pretty flexible schedules, making it pretty easy to fit into a student's schedule. I learned a lot as I was given a lot of responsibility.
cons: Start around minimum wage unless your overseer sees you fit to be given more. Some positions I've heard about are very time consuming and not worthwhile. You need to find the right position some how.

pros: You get to work with intelligent, focused students, faculty who are exceptional teachers and researchers and staff that is smart, dedicated and creative. The campus is beautiful.
cons: The only con I have come across is the parking. The garage and meters are expensive. If you park off- site and walk, you need to arrive quite early to find a spot in the neighborhood.

pros: Working with intelligent, dedicated people that embrace differences make for a fun and liberal environment. Wonderful work-life balance beliefs. I feel very empowered by management in the form of cutting edge technology, continuous learning, and a true interest from my superiors in my personal growth.
cons: Departments are silo'd and some people refuse to change, knocking down ideas that may cause them to take any kind of forward-moving action despite the university itself being a hub of technology and progress.

review_title: The best place to Study & work
pros: Great place to study. During my time at Carnegie Mellon, I worked as a research assistant, where I coordinated between our research team and the university mechanical engineering department, by telephone, email, and in person, to ensure our device met specifications. The position required the ability to multitask and follow detailed instructions and I was very satisfied.
cons: There is nothing to complain about it. Everything was amazing: teachers, technicians .

pros: Everyone that you interact with is extremely well versed in what they do.  It is very easy to talk with leaders in the field of computer science in the same building, or attend talks every week by them.
cons: Very competitive environment and can sometimes give you a bit of imposter syndrome.  Classes are not easy (machine learning)

pros: You will learn so much more than you ever could have imagined learning if you major in engineering. The faculty are doing relevant research for the vast majority of disciplines on campus so it is a great place to pursue a specific filed or a multidisciplinary path.
cons: There is no shortage of homework here. During the average week you have to be prepared to give up all 5 of your weeknights and one of your weekend nights.

review_title: Carnegie Mellon Univ is a great place to work for!
pros: Good students, professors and colleagues. Nice working environment and everybody is very nice. A good chance/way to know cutting edge knowledge and technologies, you will learn lots of things happen in the industry and academic.
cons: Work load is big, and pay is not that satisfying. Sometimes students will have endless questions.. Food on campus is not good, and there is very few choices of them you can make.

review_title: Collaboration and entrepreneurship are encouraged,if you can overcome departmental silos.
pros: It is true that collaboration is easy and encouraged here, although few stray from the bounds of their departments when looking for researchers. The research climate in this way is very positive.
cons: Be careful of what part of the university you become involved with depending on what your goals are. Although it's easy to collaborate once you find people, it can be challenging to find out what is going on elsewhere on campus.

pros: Very strong teaching team in field of computer science and software engineering. You may achieve amazing work you could not imagine here.
cons: There is no LIFE in CMU. All you got is due and due and due. It is normal you sleep after 12 just for the assignment.

review_title: Great school with great fellowship opportunities.
job_title: Jazz Orchestra Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: You get a great value when you get a fellowship. School can be almost free for you and you work only 10 hrs/week.
cons: Work can be hard. Especially with a full class load. But no body dies from it. Generally if you get into CMU with a fellowship you know how to work hard enough already.

review_title: Carnegie Mellon is a fabulous place to work
pros: You have awesome colleagues and extremely smart and motivated students. Pittsburgh is a very livable city with cheap housing and interesting neighborhoods.
cons: There is no transparency about salary (which is why I am posting!) so no way to trust that it is fair.

review_title: Hard work pays off in a supportive environment
pros: People working here are great and there is a great atmosphere for getting help.  When a problem arises, the staff likes to think of the problem as shared responsibility which leads to everyone being supportive and effective in creating solutions
cons: Hours sometimes get boring by just sitting at a desk.  There should be more staff meetings so issues can be addressed quicker as they are pretty slow with that currently

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: the organization is very professional and the working atmosphere is good there. The payment is fine for a graduate student working there as a research assistant.
cons: the work is usually time-consuming and the work load is sort of heavy there, especially for full-time graduate students who have extremely tight course schedule for every mini semester. you have to have a better understanding of your self before applying for any positions like this, otherwise you will live in the hell.

review_title: A great place to work but needs better resource allocation and more focused management.
pros: Great culture, friendly people, diversity, good teamwork and allowances for personal circumstances in adapting individual work patterns.
cons: From an employee perspective, not many; some downsides in terms of results on projects, details specified in "Advice to Management".

job_title: EXPERIENCE Teaching Assistant in San Angelo, TX
pros: Getting to know a favorite professor in a broader capacity than lecture is a treat, and I personally enjoyed helping other students learn the material. The hours are largely flexible as a significant portion of the position involves responding to student emails and grading exams or assignments.
cons: Getting everything set up with payroll services can be a convoluted process, but the new scheduling software for submitting timesheets makes getting paid easy after the initial set up.

pros: Very helpful alumni network that allows for current students to reach out easily. Lots of software companies come weekly and willing to meet on campus.
cons: Heavy focus on engineering and computer science. Needs well rounded career fairs to be open to all majors. Very tech heavy as well

pros: The project I worked on was very interesting and in depth. It gave me a lot of good experience that will be useful in the future
cons: Hard to manage the job with class work and extracurricular activities. Did not receive a lot of training at the beginning.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Reputation of university in many fields means your degree will be very useful.  Many intelligent students.  A lot of opportunity for collaboration.
cons: Some faculty don't keep up with current research trends.  Poor management style by advisors.  RAs treated as engineers more than researchers.

review_title: Great place to work, benefits people and all
pros: Very nice place to get involved in outside activities and an excellent benefits package makes it very worth it. Most of the other people here have been here for years.
cons: None, besides the making doctoral students pay for their own health insurance (which is quite a  nice insurance). The campus is very walking friendly, so don't feel bad about not finding parking

pros: Great work environment, excellent pay and benefits. Very rewarding working with  many diverse groups of people.
cons:
Parking  was expensive also the lack of places to park
Some of the buildings were like fallout shelters drabby no windows all concrete caused some workers to be depressed.

review_title: I was as happy as one could be with a student office assistant position.
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The office staff members were amazing; they were fun, friendly, trusting, and respectful of me as a student worker. I also love getting paid to take a leisurely walk across campus to deliver papers to another department.
cons: The job was very simple. I do wish that I had more responsibility in terms of database management or whatnot, but it's understandable, given my position.

pros: It's really great to work at CMU as teaching assistant, the students are really smart and amazing, you can learn a lot from them.
cons: Well, probably TAs has too much work to do. We need to hold office hours, attend lectures, grade homework, answer questions on piazza, ect

review_title: Our heart is in the work but we still want to be compensated well.
pros: Overall culture encouraged innovation and new ideas (although not so much in my specific dept). Decent communication from management. Lots of opportunities to attend "one-of-a-kind" speaking engagements. Discounts on cultural events in Pittsburgh.
cons: Availability of parking. Little opportunity for advancement. Within my department little support for professional development. High turnover in the HR department.

job_title: PhD Student in Mountain View, CA
pros: Silicon Valley campus is very close to all the major Tech companies. It helps a lot for the collaboration between companies and the university as well as spinning out start-ups out of the research done at CMU.
cons: Work/life balance is hard to accomplish. The facilities are very basic, since it is located in an ex-military base. Only two buildings are part of the CMU SV campus and there is no good food cafeterias/restaurants within the campus.

review_title: Always a great work study position
job_title: Computer Cluster Monitor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great coworkers, environment, and flexible hours for amazing pay. Management was respectful, helpful for future career opportunities, and understanding of education restrictions on working.
cons: Not very many. The work can be somewhat mindless, and at times you can interact with some difficult or rude students.

pros: You can abtain a lot from the work. The professors are very good. The labs can support you to the research you want.
cons: Sometime, the work is very hard. You need to take quite a long time to finish you task. Also, being able to write the code is a must.

pros: Nice people and nice work environment, would learn a lot if really like it. I also get chance to contact with companies, which help me get used to business in the future.
cons: People do not push the work, especially if you are still at school. But people are really nice in general. You have to have motivation for the work by yourself.

pros: It is a very friendly University. Very rich in cultural diversity and friendly co-workers/ students. Also, its one of the top universities in the US
cons: Pittsburgh is not a big city and their athletics facilities are not up to the standards of a very well known university. It lacks social life.

pros: Overall its a great experience working as a bridge between professors and students. Professors I've worked with are always great. They are willing to share all kinds of information you need.
cons: None. As long as you communicate with the professor in time about your situation, they would always be willing to help you out.

pros: Excellent exposure to many of the nation's finest minds - getting to interact with professors and students is awesome.
cons: I couldn't see a lot of cons, as I was getting compensated quite alright for my role as a TA. Couldn't have hurt to be paid a bit more, though.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA
pros: This review is speaking to the Silicon Valley campus, which still has a bit of the start-up atmosphere that was pervasive during its first 10 years. The people are very collaborative and there's a great community spirit.
cons: The campus has lost a bit of its start-up feeling since around 2013, when most all appointments had to be channeled through one of the departments. However, this has also brought some efficiencies.

review_title: An great academic environment in an open campus.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The academic community fosters innovation because there is a very open policy on campus.  Most faculty and researchers have open doors.  Some of the top experts in computer science and engineering are located here and relatively easy access to them is invaluable.
cons: As a graduate student, the downsides are the same when compared with other graduate students in other universities.

job_title: Associate Teaching Professor in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Smart minds, great colleagues, small, intimate campus, good facilities, technology readily available
cons: Extreme hard-working ethos ("My heart is in the work"), spousal hire policy not effective

review_title: Foreign born Ph.Ds do the chores
pros: Carnegie Mellon is one of the very top university in the World. For common folks its brand carries a lot of weight.
cons: The prestige of the brand drives the compensation down significantly. It hire an army of foreign born Ph.Ds doing the chores for them for cheap.

review_title: Great Learning Opportunity, No Career Future (NREC)
pros: Smart people, great opportunity to learn best practices, excellent robotics talent.  Learn all you can!
cons: Moving up is mostly politics, not ability.  There are serious structural issues with how the organization is built and managed.  You'll have to bail if you want to advance with any regularity.

review_title: Overall, nice place to work.  Retirement plan, health care & tuition benefits are great.
pros: Many growth opportunities to move throughout the college.  Free onsite professional development courses.
cons: With most jobs, the job is only as pleasant as the manager in charge.  I had more good managers than bad but there were a couple of bad apples.

pros: Carnegie Mellon University is an ispiring place to work, many smart people around, a lot of interesting research going on.
cons: Carnegie Mellon University is a very competitive environment, which sometimes might feel good, but very often it has many negative outocomes on the overall atmosphere.

review_title: Good place to be a teaching assistant
pros:
-Teaching assistants are viewed as respected positions, they can get you another job down the road
-You get to interact with professors on a much deeper level and learn a lot about a particular subject
cons:
-Grading is still boring and can overwhelm at times
-Sometimes courses change dramatically from year to year and you might have to spend time learning yourself

pros: It is one of the best graduate schools if you are a Computer Science Major. A lot of solid courses that make you stay up very late, but you really learn things.
cons: If you are not a strong-minded person, you can choose some really easy class and you dont learn anything at all

pros: Research at CMU is top notch. Lots of interdisciplinary collaboration taking place.  Research facilities top notch.  If you want to learn computer science, this is the number one place to go.  The CS classes offered here  are fantastic
cons: Does not sponsor STEM extension for international employees.  If you want to work at CMU as an international, you need to watch out the visa status.

pros: Recognize value in employees. Didn't want to let me go when I wanted to move on to another career (good thing).
cons: Pittsburgh is dull, although working at Carnegie Mellon University had a lot of perks for things to do around Pittsburgh.

job_title: Desktop Support Consultant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: 401k contributions without matching , Diverse culture both staff and students, access to university gym,library, and other resources.
cons:
